name: Millennium Biltmore Hotel Los Angeles

reviews.title: Beware
reviews.text: Booked through 3rd party website. Selected double. Clearly states double. Upon checkin, was informed they had no doubles available. However, when I check through their own website for this evening, they show doubles. Thus, either they lied to me in person, or they lie on their website.

reviews.title: Will never stay in this hotel again
reviews.text: Older building, smaller rooms, only paid wifi (even in lobby), hot tub out of order.
The lobby is impressive but the rooms need renovation. The location is very depressing, although it is situated in the city center.
reviews.title: Excellent hotel full of character

reviews.text: Our car has been taken since our arrival and we have been charged 40 usd/night without being asked to leave the car at the hotel parking or not. You don't have the keys with you and the access to the car is only via the hotel staff.
reviews.title: Comfortable stay

reviews.text: Public parkings around the hotel charge not more than 20 -25 usd/night.
reviews.title: Rooms are an embarrassment for this brand

reviews.text: We were there for a quick overnight, but we enjoyed the "experience." Staying in a hotel that's a throw back to the days of Hollywood grandeur was a unique, fun time for us. The room was your average room, with a unique decor (again, a nod to the days gone by). The bathroom is tiny, and our tub had peeling paint.
reviews.title: Beautiful Setting: Fun Experience

reviews.text: We were "promised" fluffy bathrobes, but our room didn't have any. We were also promised upon booking our room that we would be on floors 3-5, but our room was on the 11th floor. Not that we really cared about that. Another "negative" if you can call it that, was we were promised "Club Access" which was complimentary cocktail hour fare, and breakfast in the morning. What they don't tell you until you arrive is that children may not partake in this, because it's set up for business travelers. My 10 year old didn't mind, but it would have been nice if everyone in my "party" had been able to enjoy the breakfast.
reviews.title: Historic hotel with a beautiful lobby.

reviews.text: What my daughter did enjoy was the pool, and we spent a good part of our brief visit at the Biltmore Health Club. I thought the lobby was breathtaking and the staff very courteous.
reviews.title: Great Hotel. Not may eating choices around location

reviews.text: The one BEWARE I will share with possible visitors: DO NOT STAY NEAR THE ELEVATORS. In fact, if you get to your room and find yourself close to the elevators, insist on another room. Your hotel room will offer you no sound buffering, and you'll hear the "ding" of the elevators all night long. Unfortunately for us, another guest on our floor (only a room or two away from ours), came into the hallway and was loud, drunk and banging on doors for several minutes, waking us up and putting a damper on the "relaxing" mood the hotel had created for us. I can't blame the Biltmore for that, but beware, you will hear everything going on in the hallway. Be sure to turn on the rooms A/C and it will drown out some of the noise - that's how we survived the night.
reviews.title: Still a charming hotel and great location

reviews.text: And lastly - while very courteous and helpful - the VALET service will run you $40 per night, so be prepared for the cost of parking in Los Angeles. I had done my research and expected it, but if it was a surprise I would have been bummed out.
reviews.title: Grand Rooms for Celebrations, Tired Rooms for Sleeping

reviews.text: I stayed at this Historic hotel for a business meeting and saw lots of history previous guests left behind which was not cleaned. I could not believe not only the lack of cleanliness but the maintenance was not kept up. Duck tape to repair the carpets?
reviews.title: History shows

reviews.text: I just stayed at the MB for the first time for a 3 day work meeting and though it is as others noted in need for some updating, I felt it was a pleasant overall experience. My room was a suite on the 10th floor (#1077) - but was an odd layout - two small cramped bathrooms - looks like they just cut an archway between to regular rooms to create it - but it was a nice location otherwise.
reviews.title: Nice overall experience

reviews.text: Historic decor of the various common spaces and pool is really endearing, but the aerobic area could use a fan to circulate the air better and to update the equipment - it works but looks decades old. Also the AC in the whole place definitely works, in fact I was cold much of the time - it took me a while to get the knack of how to get the room temp comfortable without always going up and then down and back up...
reviews.title: You must be kidding!!!!!

reviews.text: I found the service from the staff very accommodating and would stay here again.
reviews.title: I'm not ready for a close-up Mr. DeMille!

reviews.text: No guest appreciation-HORRIBLY loud street nises-cars trucks and jackhammers all night long-Valet damaged my car I could go on-nver will recommend-spa down-no breakfast just coffee
reviews.title: Worst hotel ever

reviews.text: I am staying in this hotel right now and would never advise this.
reviews.title: Choose another hotel...........

reviews.text: It is a continual annoyance. It started when we arrived and the front desk reported that there was no availability on the 8th, 9th, 10th or 11th floor despite my earlier request. Ahhaaa the front desk man found something...... For $. 50,00 extra per night we could choose for an upgrade to the club member level on the 11th floor. And yes, WiFi was included. In the other rooms you have to pay $. 10,00 (per device!!!) per night extra. We asked for a room with a view and the front desk man found us a wonderful room, he said. We received the key and went upstairs to level 11. There we entered the room. The room was okay, but when we opened the curtains all we saw was another wall. We complained to the front deks and after 30 minutes of waiting we finally received another room. Smaller, no safe (as promised), but with somekind of a view. If you are in a club level room you can make use of breakfast and apatizers and drinks in the evening between 5pm and 8pm. We were very negatively surprised when we heard that my daughter was not allowed in the club member area. The front desk man never mentioned this and I am sure he saw my daughter on ckeck in. Especially since he has three people checked in. Then parking. They very aggresive try to sell you valet parking. Very intrusive they try to pursuade you to pay $. 40,00 per night, "Otherwise it will still be much more expensive" they said. When I mentioned that I first wanted to know what my options are, the man became very annoying and and threatened that I should be back soon, otherwise he would remove my car. Finally we parked at the otherer side of the street in a parking near the Hilton. They charge $. 30,00 for valet. There you have no in-and-out privaleges, but who needs that when you are gone all day. I paid $. 10,00 for the night. We had no stamp on our ticket, because the hotel said we did not need that. The man in the parking was very friendly and gave me the discounted Millennium Biltmore price anyway. Tonight I parked my car there again and once again I tried to get a stamp from the hotel and once again they said they never stamp tickets. That is not true because the guy from the parking let me see an example. Tomorrow we will see what happens. When you call the front desk, they always reply with: "One moment". Then they leave you on hold for at least 15 minutes. I think they wait till you give up. I forgot to mention their way of "solving" problems. My daughter is not allowed in the club lounge where they serve breakfast. So they gave me a voucher for breakfast in a restaurant downstairs. I asked for them (3 vouchers) to slide them under my door. The front desk man promised to do so. The next morning no vouchers. So i went to the club lounge. There I finally received a voucher. I asked for three, since we are staying for three days. No that was not the way to do it, the lady replied. I have to collect my vouchers every day. That is an example of the service level of the Millenniuw Biltmore. Finally the room. Not worth the money. I have seen much better for much less. I would definitely not recommend this hotel to anyone. I am sure that there are better hotels which are worth the money.
reviews.title: Very Nice Lobby and public areas. Rooms a little tired

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We were there for a trade show...hotel was full but they handled it well Great downtown location. Wonderful public areas. Staff very friendly and helpful. Rooms on the small side owing to age of hotel. Bathrooms small too, and amenities are not up to a high end standard. Coffe maker in room was good. Probably really 3.5 stars.
reviews.title: Elegant and Wonderful

reviews.text: We stayed two nights at the Biltmore and could not have been happier. We asked for a room with a view that allowed smoking and we were given a front corner room on the 4th floor with views towards Pershing Square. I really loved the huge windows that opened. The bed was probably the most comfortable bed I have ever slept on. The hotel itself is very lovely, they have a beautiful pool from the 1920's with amazing tile work. The location was perfect for exploring downtown and for using the metro and light rails to get around LA car-free, which makes LA so much more relaxing. We really loved this hotel.
reviews.title: a hotel with a feel of royalty

reviews.text: the millenium biltmore , as a hotel was above our expectations. the designs of it loby areas are really worth giving a nice look. the staff was very courteous, and very helpful and cooperative, as we had reached the hotel at 9 am, but still they had the room ready for us (with no extra charges). Inroom dining quality was quite good, and so was the morning breakfast's . if you want to stay in the down town LA area, this hotel is my strong recomendation.
reviews.title: Rundown.

reviews.text: I recently stayed three nights at the Biltmore in downtown LA while attending a Singapore Math workshop. The Biltmore is a beautiful, classy hotel with lots of history. Much to my surprise, they had a free happy hour on Wednesday night for hotel guests. The beds were great, although walls were a bit thin. There are lots of restaurants in the area. Young people will love Louie's a few blocks away. Parking is ridiculously expensive but behind hotel there are 2 different lots with parking for $10 and $15 per day instead of $45/day.
reviews.title: Fabulous history and class

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We found the hotel and the parking attendants were just standing around and were in no hurry to help us in any way. We stood around for a while after someone came to the car, then nobody helped us get the bags out of the car so we found our own luggage trolley and started loading the car ourselves. Finally when we were almost done, someone came to help us with the rest and took the trolley from us. We checked in without issue and the bellman was great but this did not excuse everything else. We got to our room and my face just fell. It was such a disappointing run down room. it was spacious but both the furniture and carpet were old and worn. The bathroom did not have any soap so we had to call the front desk and my boyfriend was put on hold for 20 minutes. Unbelievable! The shower did not have much water pressure and we had to play around with the shower head for a while just to have it release a reasonable amount of water. We wanted a nice luxurious hotel with good service and were disappointed with both. We will never stay at this hotel again.
reviews.title: Beautiful lobby, run down rooms

reviews.text: We moved here after a disastrous checkin at a dive hotel near downtown. I cannot say enough great things about this hotel. The place is beautiful, the concierge know what impeccable service really means, and the beds are as comfy as home. I needed a late-night snack and the concierge directed me to a nice little store about a block away from the hotel, where I found sandwiches, salads, and much more...all freshly made & reasonably priced. We loved staying here very much, and if we return to L.A., this will be our chosen place to stay.
reviews.title: Absolutely loved our stay here...lap of luxury!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We stayed at the Millenium because our friends were staying there, but it turned out to be a great choice. The hotel lobby, bars, cafes, lounges were all so spacious and beautiful. Each person who worked there was as nice as could be, from maid to security guard or concierge. The food was excellent there, and we ate at the restaurants more than once, although it was , of course, costly, as is typical for an LA hotel restaurant.
reviews.title: Beautiful historic hotel; great location downtown
Questions remain over security of rooms
reviews.text: Would definitely recommend for a downtown hotel with a lot more personality than usual.

reviews.title: Still using "history" as an excuse for "comfort"
reviews.text: I stayed at the Millennium Biltmore on May 21 for 5 nights. Let me start with the positive. The history of this hotel is charming. The common areas are rich in "old Hollywood history" and are absolutely stunning. It truly feels like you are stepping back in the 1920's. All of the service I experienced at this hotel was up to par or exceeded expectations. In addition, the cleanliness of both my room and common areas were good to very good.
Unfortunately, I still feel that this hotel does not live up to what the Millennium brand is meant to live up to, and therefore, they use "history" as an excuse for appearance of the guest rooms.
reviews.title: Step back in time

reviews.text: I stayed on Floor 8 in a King room. Let me explain the levels to you. Up through Floor 7 are standard rooms. Floor 8 and 9 are "upgraded standard rooms". Floor 10 and 11 are club levels and suites. I was on Floor 8 which is supposedly an upgraded standard room. I was guaranteed a club level room; however, unfortunately at check-in, no such rooms were available. As I walked off the elevator on Floor 8, you could see the hallway carpet was in a truly bad state with the peeling, fading, and fraying. Once I entered my room, I was fairly pleased; however, I would say that Floor 8 should be a standard room. It was clean and spacious. It did have a LCD Flat Panel TV/ MP3 compatible clock radio, a large desk and great lighting. It is ashame to think that Floors 2-7 still do not have these features (which is where I stayed on my last visit).
reviews.title: Biltmore Hotel.. LA

reviews.text: Overall, because of my room on the 8th Floor, my visit was better than last time, despite not being placed in the guaranteed room of my booking. However, Floors 8 and 9 are the minimum for what I would pay for on a standard rate. I would be upset paying more than $100 a night for a room below Floor 8. I can see paying the normal current going rate for Floors 8 and higher.
reviews.title: A nice comfortable hotel, but watch out for parking charges

reviews.text: As I said, the common areas are beautiful and the location downtown is good. Parking is $40 with unlimited in and out privileges, which is competitive with the area. If you do want lower priced parking, there is a garage just outside the rear entrance to the hotel (although I'm not sure if that includes in and out). The indoor pool and fitness center are amazing and also throws you back to the 1920's.
reviews.title: Amazing history, renovated rooms!

reviews.text: I stayed in this beautiful historic hotel for 3 nights while visiting LA. The gorgeous lobby and bar area gives you a feeling of nostalgia. The home of the Oscars in the 30's and beyond, this hotel has a special air about it. The gallery bar was a busy but fun place to end our evenings.
reviews.title: A Touch of Class

reviews.text: We arrived early in the AM fully prepared to leave our luggage and check in later in the afternoon. We were pleasantly surprised when they checked us in immediately and we were in our room by 10 am. Our room was very large with plenty of space for the 4 of us to spread out.
reviews.title: What everyone else is true, but MY tip is...

reviews.text: The beds were comfortable and our room location was very quiet.
reviews.title: Gorgeous Historic Hotel with so so service and rooms
Classic hotel needs a facelift
reviews.text: The Concierge was extremely helpful in hiring a driver to take us around LA for the day as well as recommending restaurants in the area thatt were outstanding.

reviews.title: Good hotel for a few nights
reviews.text: I would not hesitate to recommend staying at this hotel and can't wait to stay there again.
Great location in downtown close to Disney Concert Hall. Beautiful historic building.
reviews.title: Downtown Los Angeles

reviews.text: Parking is quite expensive at the hotel but we parked across the street on a lot for fraction. Weekend parking is a deal for $5 a day.
reviews.title: Old School

reviews.text: We spent one night at the Millennium Biltmore this past weekend. Overall, we were really pleased. The staff were all very friendly, especially Jessica at the Front Desk, who I'm pretty sure upgraded our room for us. We paid $160 for the night, which seemed reasonable. Unfortunately, valet is $40/day. If we hadn't been traveling with children and loads of luggage, we would've parked at a neighboring garage or parking lot for less.
reviews.title: In search of some tea!

reviews.text: The hotel is definitely old-fashioned but full of character and history. I've been staying in mostly modern hotels, so it was a welcome change. I enjoyed walking around and looking at all of the unusual details; the health club/indoor pool- incredible 20's style, beautiful stairwell, gallery, old photos, lobby.
reviews.title: Vast, gorgeous, lobbies, much less to love elsewhere

reviews.text: Our room/bathroom were a decent size, especially considering it's in the city. There was a huge walk-in closet. I personally liked the old details in the room; vintage windows, doorknobs, etc. We also appreciated the map we were given that pointed out all of the nearby restaurants, which are within walking distance.
reviews.title: Very Interesting good Hotel

description: The historic Millennium Biltmore Hotel has been a legendary Los Angeles landmark since 1923. With exquisite Spanish-Italian Renaissance architecture, including stunning hand-painted ceilings, it’s rich history is most noted for its connection with the Oscars - the founding banquet for the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences was held in the Crystal Ballroom in 1927, where the original “Oscar” statuette was sketched on a Biltmore napkin, and nine Academy Awards banquets were held in the Biltmore Bowl during the '30s and '40s.
